contentrichtext.text: {{cleanup|date=September 2009}} {{update|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox Company | company_name = Yogi Tea | company_logo = [[Image:Yogi Tea Logo.png|center|150px|Yogi Tea logo]]| company_type = Private| num_employees = 150| foundation = 1984| location = [[Springfield, Oregon]]| industry = [[Beverage]]| products = [[Tea]]| homepage = [http://www.yogitea.com Yogi Tea]| }} '''Yogi Tea''' creates and manufactures a wide variety of teas, including green, herbal, black and red tea. Yogi Tea is part of East West Tea Company, LLC (EWTC) - former Golden Temple of Oregon, LLC. EWTC employs about 150 people in the United States and Europe,<ref name=eurg>{{Cite news | last = McDonald | first = Sherri Buri | coauthors = | title = Yogi's widow sues managers | newspaper = The Register Guard | location = Springfield, Oregon | pages = | publisher = | date = 14 December 2010 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> with offices in Springfield and [[Portland, Oregon]], and in [[Hamburg, Germany]]. ==History== [[Yogi Bhajan]], an Indian spiritual teacher who brought the Sikh religion to the West, began teaching [[Kundalini Yoga]] in America in 1969. After each yoga class, he served a special spice tea to his students, which they affectionately named "Yogi Tea". The tea was a blend of five traditional [[Ayurveda|Ayurvedic]] spices: [[cardamom]] seed, [[cinnamon]] bark, [[clove]] bud, [[ginger|ginger root]] and [[black pepper]]. Ayurvedic medicine holds that this combination of spices has unique, healthful properties, so they are still included in many current Yogi Tea formulas. In the 1970s, students of Yogi Bhajan opened Golden Temple Vegetarian Restaurants in the United States, Canada and Europe. Through these restaurants, the first batches of Yogi Tea were sold to the public, and by 1984, the Yogi Tea Company was born. Over the next couple of years, the business grew to nationwide distribution, with three flavors of finely ground spices packaged in teabags. Then in 1988, Yogi Teaâ€™s team of herbalists expanded the line to include a number of formulas developed to address specific health needs. In 2010 Yogi Tea was sued by Yogi Bhajan's widow Bibiji Inderjit Kaur Puri,<ref name=eurg/> and the State of Oregon.<ref name=orgstate>{{Citation| last = McDonald| first = Sherri Buri| title = State targets Golden Temple| newspaper = The Eugene Register Guard| date = November 10, 2010| url = | archiveurl =| archivedate =| accessdate = }}</ref> The suits allege that trusted advisers of the Yogi had forged documents regarding to their take-over of the company, exclusion of the family from the board, excessive compensation for the executives, and the abandonment of what Bibiji describes as orthodox Sikh practices.<ref name=eurg/><ref>{{cite news|title=Records in lawsuit claim Golden Temple executives drew excessive compensation|url=http://www.statesmanjournal.com/article/20110513/BUSINESS/105130316/Records-lawsuit-claim-Golden-Temple-executives-drew-excessive-compensation?odyssey=mod{{!}}newswell|text|Home|p|accessdate=14 May 2011|newspaper=[[Statesman Journal]]|date=May. 12, 2011|agency=The Associated Press}}</ref> The 2007 sale spurred numerous other lawsuits, including one against law firm [[Schwabe, Williamson & Wyatt]], as well as the parent company filing for bankruptcy protection.<ref>{{cite news|last=Culverwell|first=Wendy|title=Schwabe Williamson sued for $230M in Yogi Bhajan-related suit|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/blog/2012/02/suits-fly-when-100m-company-sold-for.html|accessdate=February 24, 2012|newspaper=Portland Business Journal|date=February 24, 2012}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.goldentemple.com Golden Temple] *[http://www.yogitea.eu/en/ Yogi Tea] *[https://www.facebook.com/YogiTea?fref=ts Yogi Tea Community on Facebook.com] [[Category:Tea brands]] [[Category:Privately held companies based in Oregon]] [[Category:1984 establishments in Oregon]]
